texture.layers package¶

Submodules¶

texture.layers.bilinearmodel module¶

Keras layer for weighted bilinear modeling of two 1-D feature vectors

TODO: - tests for BilinearModel layer

texture.layers.bilinearmodel.BilinearModel(Layer)[source]¶

Weighted bilinear model of two inputs. Useful for learning a model of linear interactions between seperate feature types (e.g., texture X spatial) or scales (e.g., dense X dilated), etc.

#TODO: finish docstring

texture.layers.encoding module¶

Keras 2.0+ / TensorFlow implementation of learnable encoding layer proposed in:

Hang Zhang, Jia Xue, and Kristin Dana. “Deep TEN: Texture Encoding Network.” The IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) 2017

Borrows from PyTorch implementation released by Hang Zhang: https://github.com/zhanghang1989/PyTorch-Encoding

class texture.layers.encoding.Encoding(K, dropout=None, l2_normalize=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: keras.engine.base_layer.Layer

Residual encoding layer with learnable codebook and scaling factors.

Encodes an collection of NxD features into set of KxD vectors. Unlike PyTorch implementation, D is inferred automatically from input_shape.

Allowed `input_shape`s are (batches, N, D) or (batches, H, W, D).

Parameters:
  • K (int) – Number of codewords to learn
  • dropout (float, optional) –
    Dropout rate between [0.0,1.0), or None, default=`None`.
    Currently applied to scale factors, which is equivalent to zeroing out dropout fraction of the aggregated codewords.
  • l2_normalize (bool, optional) – Whether to normalize output vectors, default=`True`.
  • TODO –
    • make sure dropout only applied during training

texture.layers.kernelpooling module¶

Implementation of polynomial Kernel Pooling layer with learnable composition: @conference{cui2017cvpr,

title = {Kernel Pooling for Convolutional Neural Networks}, author = {Yin Cui and Feng Zhou and Jiang Wang and Xiao Liu and Yuanqing Lin and Serge Belongie}, url = {https://vision.cornell.edu/se3/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/cui2017cvpr.pdf}, year = {2017}, booktitle = {Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR)},

} _generate_sketch_matrix() borrowed from: https://github.com/ronghanghu/tensorflow_compact_bilinear_pooling sequential_batch_[i]ff from the same repo would be useful for avoiding OOM errors w/ arbitrary batch size

  • does source need an update?
class texture.layers.kernelpooling.AlphaInitializer(gamma)[source]¶

Bases: object

Callable for setting initial composition_weights given gamma.
Following the Taylor series expansion of the RBF kernel:
K_RBF(x, y) = Sum_i(beta *
rac{(2*gamma)^i}{i!})
We assume that input vectors are L2-normalized, in which case we have:
(alpha_i)^2 = exp(-2*gamma)*

rac{(2*gamma)^i}{i!}

class texture.layers.kernelpooling.KernelPooling(p=3, d_i=4096, seed=0, gamma=0.0001, X_train=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: keras.engine.base_layer.Layer

Kernel Pooling layer with learnable composition weights. Takes convolution output volume as input, outputs a Taylor series kernel of order p. By default the weights are initialized to approximate the Gaussian RBF kernel. See the paper for more detailed exposition. Kernel vectors are average pooled over all spatial locations (h_i, w_j).

output_shape=(batches,1+C+Sum(d_2,…,d_p)), for input_shape=(batches,H,W,C). This implementation follows the paper in assuming that d_i=d_bar for all i>=2, so d=1+C+(p-1)*d_i.

Parameters:
  • p (int, optional) – Order of the polynomial approximation, default=3
  • d_i (int, optional) – Dimensionality of output features of each order {2,…,p}, default=4096.
  • seed (int, optional) – Random seed for generating sketch matrices. If given, will use range(seed, seed+p) for h, and range(seed+p, seed+2p) for s.
  • gamma (float, optional) – RBF kernel approximation parameter, default=1e-4.
  • X_train (array, optional) – Training set of features from which to estimate gamma s.t. kernel closely approximates RBF. If provided, will use reciprocal of mean inner product values. Otherwise, default used.
